articles.title: Why we launched Denmark’s second Young Academy (and what’s different about it)
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02520-yYATSI aims to represent scientists based in academia and in industry, and to build bridges between the two sectors.
articles.content:
YATSI fellows visiting NKT Photonics in Birkerød, Denmark.Credit: Tom Jersø/Danish Academy of Technical Sciences

As early-career researchers navigate increasingly complex challenges — from climate change to digital transformation — they need to be empowered to take bold steps, form lasting networks and champion science that serves society.

This is where National Young Academies come in. Typically founded by scholars at the beginning of their independent research careers, Young Academies give a voice to and represent the interests of young scientists in academia, helping them to be heard by national governments and wider society. There are now more than 60 Young Academies (and similar networks) worldwide.

But in 2023, a different kind of Young Academy launched in Denmark. YATSI, the Young Academy of Technology, Science and Innovation, aims to give a voice to early-career researchers and professionals in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics), with representatives from both academia and industry, and also to strengthen collaboration between the two sectors.

YATSI’s three founders (Sandra Wingaard Thrane, Janus Juul Eriksen Andreas Hougaard Laustsen-Kiel and Kirsten Marie Ørnsbjerg Jensen) felt there was a need for a Young Academy that focused exclusively on STEM. Thrane co-founded Bactolife, a biotechnology start-up in Copenhagen, in 2017 and is now its chief scientific officer. Eriksen is a chemistry researcher at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU) in Kongens Lyngby. Laustsen-Kiel leads the Center for Antibody Technologies at DTU, and is also the co-founder of eight companies. Jensen is a researcher in nanomaterials at the University of Copenhagen.

Careers advice from scientists in industry

YATSI now has four physical meetings a year and several ad hoc meetings across its three committees. Meetings are hosted by universities and companies, and cover topics that range from career development to STEM education and policy. Fellows are selected on the basis of written applications and in-person interviews. To be eligible, applicants must have completed a PhD (or equivalent) within the past seven years. Membership lasts for five years, and the academy is governed by a five-member council.

We hope to reach a full capacity of around 40 members by 2027 (the number is capped to optimize communication, networking and teamwork, but also to be representative of early-career STEM professionals in Denmark).

Our current fellows come from six universities and nine companies or start-ups across Denmark, and have a variety of STEM backgrounds. Their specialisms encompass physics, chemistry, engineering, food, biology, information technology, cybersecurity and many more fields. There is a balanced and diverse mix of industry and academic profiles, with both Danish people and researchers from other countries who are working in Denmark. For this reason, the lingua franca of YATSI is English. Speaking as a French researcher based in Denmark, joining YATSI is a great opportunity to network with other scientists at a similar career stage. And as a member of YATSI’s Interact committee, I have helped to collate advice around effective industry–academia interactions.

Policy, Inspire, Interact

YATSI has three committees. Its Policy committee aims to ensure that the voices of early-career professionals are heard in conversations around university education, research funding and personal development. The committee also highlights career opportunities in Denmark and Europe.

There is a recognized need for closer collaboration between academic science and industrial commercialization. The Policy committee is gathering support for an academia–industry sabbatical-exchange programme aimed at giving participants a better understanding of the real-world relevance of academic research and helping to ensure that industry practices are informed by state-of-the-art scientific knowledge.

Denmark’s Best Science Meme is one example of how YATSI’s Inspire committee strives to engage the public, to illustrate the breadth and diversity of STEM in Denmark and to disseminate knowledge about STEM research and innovation.
articles.reasoning: The article describes the launch of Denmark's second Young Academy focused on STEM early-career researchers from both academia and industry, fostering collaboration, career development, and policy influence. This initiative has a broad positive impact by empowering young scientists, bridging academia and industry, and promoting STEM education and innovation, benefiting society at large.
articles.personality_title: Denmark launches a new Young Academy to connect STEM researchers and industry
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Young Academies are groups that support early-career researchers by giving them a voice in science and society. There are over 60 such academies worldwide, usually focusing on academics. 

**What happened** – In 2023, Denmark started a different kind of Young Academy called YATSI (Young Academy of Technology, Science and Innovation). It brings together early-career researchers from both universities and companies, focusing only on STEM fields like science, technology, engineering, and math. YATSI meets four times a year and includes members from six universities and nine businesses across Denmark. Members are selected through an application and interview process and serve for five years.

**Impact** – YATSI is unique because it bridges the gap between academic research and industry. This helps young scientists understand real-world problems and share knowledge that can improve business and innovation. The academy also works to influence policies on education and research funding and encourages public interest in STEM through activities like Denmark’s Best Science Meme contest.

**What's next step** – YATSI plans to grow to about 40 members by 2027 to keep communication effective while representing Denmark’s early-career STEM professionals. They are also working on programs like a sabbatical exchange to let researchers experience both academic and industry environments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Denmark’s new Young Academy, YATSI, connects early-career STEM researchers from academia and industry to boost collaboration, career growth, and science policy influence.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Danemark lance une nouvelle Jeune Académie pour relier chercheurs STEM et industrie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Jeunes Académies sont des groupes qui soutiennent les chercheurs en début de carrière en leur donnant une voix dans la science et la société. Il en existe plus de 60 dans le monde, généralement axées sur le milieu universitaire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2023, le Danemark a créé une nouvelle Jeune Académie appelée YATSI (Jeune Académie de Technologie, Science et Innovation). Elle réunit des chercheurs débutants des universités et des entreprises, uniquement dans les domaines STEM (science, technologie, ingénierie et mathématiques). YATSI organise quatre réunions par an et compte des membres issus de six universités et neuf entreprises au Danemark. Les membres sont choisis via une candidature et un entretien, pour un mandat de cinq ans.

**Impact** – YATSI est unique car elle fait le lien entre la recherche académique et l’industrie. Cela aide les jeunes scientifiques à mieux comprendre les problèmes concrets et à partager des connaissances qui améliorent l’innovation. L’académie agit aussi sur les politiques liées à l’éducation et au financement de la recherche, et suscite l’intérêt du public pour les STEM avec des actions comme le concours du meilleur mème scientifique danois.

**Prochaines étapes** – YATSI prévoit d’atteindre environ 40 membres d’ici 2027 pour garder une communication efficace tout en représentant les jeunes professionnels STEM du Danemark. Elle développe aussi des programmes comme un échange sabbatique pour faire découvrir aux chercheurs les environnements académique et industriel.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle Jeune Académie danoise, YATSI, réunit jeunes chercheurs STEM du milieu universitaire et industriel pour renforcer collaboration, carrière et influence sur les politiques scientifiques.

articles.title: Christine Lagarde: Joining the Eurozone will provide Bulgaria with stability
articles.summary: The country will have a say in important decisions regarding monetary policy and economic stability in the eurozone, said the president of the ECB.
articles.content:
The country will have a say in important decisions regarding monetary policy and economic stability in the eurozone, said the president of the ECB.

Frankfurt am Main – Joining the eurozone will provide Bulgaria with stability as part of the currency area, said the President of the European Central Bank (ECB) Christine Lagarde in response to a question from BTA at the press conference following the two-day ECB meeting on interest rate determination.

The main task of the ECB is to maintain price stability in the medium term, which will also benefit Bulgaria, Lagarde explained. According to her, adopting the euro will bring significant benefits to Bulgaria, but proper management of the transition to the new currency is also important.

Now Bulgaria will be part of a market with 350 million consumers, which will open new opportunities for investment and growth, said ECB President Christine Lagarde.

She expressed her satisfaction that Bulgaria will become part of the common European currency area and welcomed the appointment of the Governor of the Bulgarian National Bank Dimitar Radev to the ECB Governing Council as an observer until the country’s actual membership on January 1.

Bulgaria will have a vote, just like any other country in the eurozone, and will be able to actively participate in discussions on the monetary policy of the European Central Bank, Lagarde said.

The President of the ECB believes that Bulgaria will benefit from the advantages of the euro and will be able to continue developing its economy in a stable and predictable monetary environment.

Bulgaria will officially adopt the euro and will be the 21st member of the eurozone from January 1, 2026 – 19 years after the country’s accession to the European Union. The EU Council unanimously voted on July 8 this year on the final decisions related to the adoption of the euro in Bulgaria. With this, the procedure was completed, after earlier that same day the European Parliament also approved by a large majority the report on the introduction of the single European currency by Bulgaria. (11.09.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant economic and monetary integration milestone for Bulgaria joining the eurozone, which will provide stability, growth opportunities, and a voice in important monetary policy decisions affecting millions of people. This has broad societal and economic impact beyond a niche audience and is well detailed.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria to join eurozone in 2026, gaining economic stability and a stronger voice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria has been part of the European Union for 19 years and is preparing to adopt the euro as its official currency. The eurozone is a group of European countries that use the euro and share a single monetary policy managed by the European Central Bank (ECB).

**What happened** – On July 8, 2025, the European Union Council approved Bulgaria’s plan to join the eurozone starting January 1, 2026. The European Parliament also supported this decision. Christine Lagarde, president of the ECB, welcomed Bulgaria’s entry and noted that the Governor of the Bulgarian National Bank, Dimitar Radev, has been appointed as an observer on the ECB Governing Council before full membership.

**Impact** – Joining the eurozone means Bulgaria will have a say in decisions about interest rates and economic policies that affect all member countries. It will also bring price stability and a predictable financial environment. Bulgaria will join a market of 350 million consumers, which can attract more investment and help the country’s economy grow.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria will officially switch to the euro on January 1, 2026. Before that, the country will prepare for the change by adjusting its financial systems and informing its citizens. After joining, Bulgaria will fully participate in the ECB’s decision-making process with voting rights.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria’s adoption of the euro in 2026 will strengthen its economy by providing stability and a direct role in Europe’s monetary decisions.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bulgarie rejoindra la zone euro en 2026 pour plus de stabilité économique et une voix renforcée
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie fait partie de l’Union européenne depuis 19 ans et se prépare à adopter l’euro comme monnaie officielle. La zone euro regroupe des pays européens qui utilisent l’euro et partagent une politique monétaire commune gérée par la Banque centrale européenne (BCE).

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 8 juillet 2025, le Conseil de l’Union européenne a approuvé le plan de la Bulgarie pour rejoindre la zone euro à partir du 1er janvier 2026. Le Parlement européen a également soutenu cette décision. Christine Lagarde, présidente de la BCE, a accueilli favorablement l’entrée de la Bulgarie et a annoncé la nomination du gouverneur de la Banque nationale bulgare, Dimitar Radev, comme observateur au Conseil des gouverneurs de la BCE avant l’adhésion complète.

**Impact** – En rejoignant la zone euro, la Bulgarie pourra participer aux décisions concernant les taux d’intérêt et les politiques économiques qui affectent tous les pays membres. Cela apportera aussi une stabilité des prix et un environnement financier prévisible. La Bulgarie intégrera un marché de 350 millions de consommateurs, ce qui peut attirer plus d’investissements et aider à la croissance de son économie.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bulgarie adoptera officiellement l’euro le 1er janvier 2026. Avant cela, le pays préparera la transition en adaptant ses systèmes financiers et en informant ses citoyens. Après l’adhésion, la Bulgarie participera pleinement aux décisions de la BCE avec un droit de vote.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’adoption de l’euro par la Bulgarie en 2026 renforcera son économie grâce à la stabilité et à un rôle direct dans les décisions monétaires européennes.
articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria se unirá a la eurozona en 2026, ganando estabilidad económica y una voz más fuerte
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria ha sido parte de la Unión Europea durante 19 años y se está preparando para adoptar el euro como su moneda oficial. La eurozona es un grupo de países europeos que usan el euro y comparten una política monetaria común gestionada por el Banco Central Europeo (BCE).

**Qué sucedió** – El 8 de julio de 2025, el Consejo de la Unión Europea aprobó el plan de Bulgaria para unirse a la eurozona a partir del 1 de enero de 2026. El Parlamento Europeo también apoyó esta decisión. Christine Lagarde, presidenta del BCE, dio la bienvenida a la entrada de Bulgaria y anunció que el gobernador del Banco Nacional de Bulgaria, Dimitar Radev, ha sido nombrado observador en el Consejo de Gobierno del BCE antes de la membresía completa.

**Impacto** – Al unirse a la eurozona, Bulgaria tendrá voz en las decisiones sobre tasas de interés y políticas económicas que afectan a todos los países miembros. También tendrá estabilidad en los precios y un entorno financiero predecible. Bulgaria entrará a un mercado de 350 millones de consumidores, lo que puede atraer más inversiones y ayudar al crecimiento de su economía.

**Próximo paso** – Bulgaria adoptará oficialmente el euro el 1 de enero de 2026. Antes de eso, preparará la transición ajustando sus sistemas financieros e informando a sus ciudadanos. Después de unirse, Bulgaria participará plenamente en la toma de decisiones del BCE con derecho a voto.

**Resumen en una frase** – La adopción del euro por Bulgaria en 2026 fortalecerá su economía al proporcionar estabilidad y un papel directo en las decisiones monetarias de Europa.

articles.title: S. Migaľ: The Ministry accelerated the absorption of EU funds from the Slovakia Program by ten percent
articles.summary: According to the Minister of Investments and Regional Development Samuel Migaľ, his department has managed to improve the absorption of EU funds from the Slovakia Program.
articles.content:
According to the Minister of Investments and Regional Development Samuel Migaľ, his department has managed to improve the absorption of EU funds from the Slovakia Program.

Bratislava – The Ministry of Investments, Regional Development and Informatization (MIRRI) of the Slovak Republic has accelerated the drawdown of EU funds from the Slovakia Program to a level of ten percent. The ministry also reports positive results in the Fund for Just Transition and in processing grant applications, which are being processed fifty percent faster. This was reported on Friday by the communication department of MIRRI, according to TASR.

“Since our arrival, the drawdown from the Slovakia Program has increased to 10.1%, which represents more than 1.27 billion euros. The previous leadership of the ministry, led by Richard Raši (Hlas-SD) and Michal Kaliňák, managed to draw only five percent of EU funds in almost two years,” said the Minister of Investments, Regional Development and Informatization Samuel Migaľ (independent). According to him, the new MIRRI team achieved the same level in less than half a year and demonstrated that the ministry can operate professionally and efficiently under quality leadership.

Not only has the drawdown of EU funds accelerated, but also the process of handling applications for non-repayable financial contributions, from an average of 80 days to 43 days, with MIRRI’s goal being to reach 40 days. The ministry also perceives positive progress in the Fund for Just Transition, with 38 contracted projects as of September 5, 2025. At the same time, the drawdown has doubled compared to March of this year.

“The former leadership left us a full ministry of unresolved issues,” concluded Migaľ. (September 12)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant improvement in the absorption and processing of EU funds by the Slovak Ministry of Investments, which implies more efficient use of resources for regional development and just transition projects. This has a broad positive impact on public infrastructure and economic development in Slovakia, benefiting society at large. The article provides clear context and measurable progress, focusing on a single topic.
articles.personality_title: Slovakia speeds up use of EU funds, doubling progress in months
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Slovakia receives money from the European Union (EU) to support projects that improve the country, like building roads and helping communities change to cleaner energy. The Ministry of Investments, Regional Development and Informatization (MIRRI) manages this money.

**What happened** – Since new leaders took charge at MIRRI, they have increased the amount of EU money used from 5% to over 10% in less than six months. This means they spent more than 1.27 billion euros on projects. They also made the process of approving requests for money faster, cutting the time from 80 days to 43 days.

**Impact** – The faster spending and quicker approvals mean that important projects can start sooner, helping communities develop and switch to cleaner energy faster. For example, the Fund for Just Transition, which helps areas affected by changing industries, now has 38 projects signed and has used twice as much money as earlier this year.

**What's next step** – MIRRI aims to approve funding requests even faster, hoping to reduce the waiting time to 40 days. They will continue to manage the funds carefully to support more projects that improve life in Slovakia.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Slovakia’s ministry has doubled the speed of using EU funds and cut approval times, helping more projects get started quickly to improve the country.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Slovaquie accélère l'utilisation des fonds européens, doublant les progrès en quelques mois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Slovaquie reçoit de l'argent de l'Union européenne (UE) pour soutenir des projets qui améliorent le pays, comme construire des routes et aider les communautés à passer à une énergie plus propre. Le ministère des Investissements, du Développement régional et de l'Informatique (MIRRI) gère cet argent.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Depuis l'arrivée de nouvelles équipes au MIRRI, la part des fonds européens utilisés est passée de 5 % à plus de 10 % en moins de six mois. Cela signifie que plus de 1,27 milliard d'euros ont été dépensés pour des projets. Le ministère a aussi accéléré le traitement des demandes de financement, réduisant le délai de 80 à 43 jours.

**Impact** – Cette accélération permet de lancer les projets importants plus rapidement, aidant les communautés à se développer et à adopter une énergie plus propre. Par exemple, le Fonds pour la Transition Juste, qui aide les régions touchées par les changements industriels, compte maintenant 38 projets signés et a utilisé deux fois plus d'argent que plus tôt cette année.

**Prochaine étape** – Le MIRRI souhaite encore réduire le temps d'approbation des demandes à 40 jours. Il continuera à gérer les fonds avec soin pour soutenir davantage de projets qui améliorent la vie en Slovaquie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le ministère slovaque a doublé la vitesse d'utilisation des fonds européens et réduit les délais d'approbation, permettant de démarrer plus rapidement des projets pour améliorer le pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Eslovaquia acelera el uso de fondos de la UE, duplicando el progreso en meses
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Eslovaquia recibe dinero de la Unión Europea (UE) para apoyar proyectos que mejoran el país, como construir carreteras y ayudar a las comunidades a cambiar a energía más limpia. El Ministerio de Inversiones, Desarrollo Regional e Informatización (MIRRI) administra este dinero.

**Qué pasó** – Desde que nuevos líderes asumieron en MIRRI, han aumentado la cantidad de fondos de la UE usados del 5 % a más del 10 % en menos de seis meses. Esto significa que gastaron más de 1,27 mil millones de euros en proyectos. También hicieron que el proceso para aprobar solicitudes de dinero sea más rápido, reduciendo el tiempo de 80 a 43 días.

**Impacto** – Gastar más rápido y aprobar más rápido significa que los proyectos importantes pueden comenzar antes, ayudando a las comunidades a desarrollarse y a cambiar a energía más limpia más rápido. Por ejemplo, el Fondo para la Transición Justa, que ayuda a las áreas afectadas por cambios en las industrias, ahora tiene 38 proyectos firmados y ha usado el doble de dinero que a principios de año.

**Próximo paso** – MIRRI quiere aprobar las solicitudes aún más rápido, esperando reducir el tiempo de espera a 40 días. Continuarán gestionando los fondos cuidadosamente para apoyar más proyectos que mejoren la vida en Eslovaquia.

**Resumen en una frase** – El ministerio de Eslovaquia ha duplicado la velocidad en el uso de fondos de la UE y reducido los tiempos de aprobación, ayudando a que más proyectos comiencen rápido para mejorar el país.
